Ask HN: Open-source admin/control panel templates?
text:
As a backend engineer with minimal design skills, I often have to resort to templates in order to create a decent user experience for apps that I create here and there. I have been using Tabler (https://tabler.io) a lot lately, but I'm curious about what others are using.

Why open source? Because of legal reasons, of course, but also because code quality tends to be much better, and commercial templates are bloated and convoluted, trying to squeeze as many features as possible to catch the eye of potential customers.

My newsletter is making $2k per month with 7k subscribers – AMA
text:
Hi HN!

Roughly two years ago when the pandemic had people shifting to a WFH environment, I started a twice-weekly newsletter called Workspaces that gives readers a behind the scenes tour of their favorite entrepreneurs, designers, developers, etc. new desk setups.

Growth has remained consistent week to week, relying on the featured guests Twitter presence to help spread the word.

I have featured 175 workspaces to date (70+ more in the backlog) and have grown the newsletter to 7,000 subscribers while maintaining a >50% open rate.

I published the fist 117 editions of the newsletter without a sponsor. I had inbound requests but I was focused on growing the subscriber base as much as possible. With the new year, I shifted this focus slightly and began offering one sponsor slot per newsletter edition.

Since then, the newsletter has been sold out weekly and the price has risen from the initial $150 to $250, earning $2,000 per month from sponsorships.

I think it’s important to note that this was not an immediate cash cow… sending out 117 editions of a newsletter without receiving a dime can be draining. You have to truly enjoy the content you are putting out (I do!).

However, I think this shows that consistency rules and as long as you continue to show up, put out great content and iterate based on feedback you will continue to see your newsletter grow and ultimately the money will come.

Happy to answer any questions around newsletter growth, finding sponsors, etc!

Any opportunities for hyperskilled labor, preferably online and pseudonymously?
text:
Not an adult, worsening home situation - which wasn't great in the first place, so could really do with quick money. Assume skill/competence is not a barrier.

The best method know of is ImmuneFi's bug bounties: https://immunefi.com/explore

Anyone who has the skills necessary to find a vuln can instantly convert them into money, without any barriers like formal credentials or onboarding processes (for which I have no time).

What other opportunities (in any sector, not necessarily CS-related) share the same characteristics?

Ask HN: How to monitor a sea fiber cable?
text:
Recently there was a news[0] about how a national intelligence agency tried to monitor data transmitted via a sea fiber optic cable called SAFE[1] on a foreign country.

Keeping aside the politics, is it feasible to monitor and sniff data out the sea fiber directly?

Wikipedia says the cable transmits data at 440Gb/s. So I'm assuming they cannot store a large portion of the data for future analysis. Further, since this was carried in a foreign country, they might not have access to a data center, nor they can transmit it back to the home country (it would need bandwidth of another sea cable). And lastly, I'm guessing most of the traffic must be encrypted.

So how are they doing it? If the news is incorrect, it is even possible to do it for anyone with "a device" that be taken to a foreign country in a plane?

0: https://www.msn.com/en-in/news/other/mauritius-snooping-scandal-%E2%80%94-the-moustache-man-from-india-in-the-centre-of-the-storm/ar-AAZVzrB

1: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAFE_(cable_system)
